definitions.definition: to break something suddenly with a sharp noise; to be broken in this way

examples.text: The wind had snapped the tree in two.
He snapped a twig off a bush.
Suddenly, the rope snapped.
The branch she was standing on must have snapped off.
One of the table's legs had been snapped off.
She picked up the pencil and snapped it in two.
A passing tourist snapped the incident.
She seemed oblivious to the crowds of photographers snapping away.

definitions.definition: to move, or to move something, into a particular position quickly, especially with a sudden sharp noise

examples.text: The lid snapped shut.
His eyes snapped open.
He snapped to attention and saluted.
The plastic pieces snap together to make a replica of a dinosaur.
She snapped the bag shut.

definitions.definition: to speak or say something in an impatient, usually angry, voice

examples.text: ‘Don't just stand there,’ she snapped.
I was tempted to snap back angrily at him.
He snapped a reply.
‘How should I know?’ Jen snapped back.
He lost his temper and snapped irritably at the children.
The dogs snarled and snapped at our heels.

definitions.definition: to suddenly be unable to control your feelings any longer because the situation has become too difficult

examples.text: My patience finally snapped.
When he said that, something snapped inside her.
And that did it. I snapped.
I guess he just snapped.

definitions.definition: to fasten a piece of clothing with a snap
to start play by passing the ball back between your legs

examples.text: Time will not be resumed until the ball is snapped on the next play.

definitions.definition: to shout at somebody in an angry way, especially without reason
to make a sharp noise by moving your second or third finger quickly against your thumb, to attract somebody’s attention, or to mark the beat of music, for example

examples.text: He snapped his fingers for the waiter.
She only has to snap her fingers and her assistant comes running.

definitions.definition: to make an effort to stop feeling unhappy or depressed; to help somebody to stop feeling unhappy

examples.text: You've been depressed for weeks. It's time you snapped out of it.

definitions.definition: used, especially in orders, to tell somebody to start working harder or more quickly

wordOrigin: late 15th cent. (in the senses ‘make a sudden audible bite’ and ‘quick sharp biting sound’): probably from Middle Dutch or Middle Low German snappen ‘seize’; partly imitative.
